text:
Hi I'm Jake Burns Enterprise
Strategist with AWS.

Cloud computing is the on-demand
delivery of IT resources

over the internet with pay-as-you-go
pricing.

Instead of maintaining
your own servers and data centers,

you can use the cloud to acquire
technology such as compute,

storage, database, and other
services on an as-needed
basis.

This is similar to how the power
company delivers electricity

when consumers flip a switch
to turn on the lights in their
home.

The consumer does not have to
build their own power plant—the

power company builds and manages
the plant for you.

With the cloud, your provider
maintains the technology

infrastructure in a secure
environment, and you can access

these resources through the internet
to develop and run your applications.

Traditional IT can force you
to over provision data centers

to ensure you have enough
capacity to handle business

operations at the peak levels
of activity.

In the cloud, you can provision
exactly what you need, when

you need it, and instantly
scale up or down as needed.

You can avoid the inefficiencies
and wasted resources of over

provisioning while ensuring
that you have the resources

you need to run your business
and serve your customers.

This, combined with the economies
of scale of the cloud, typically

results in significant
cost savings.

For example, Dow Jones has estimated
that migrating their data centers

to AWS will contribute
to a global savings of $100

million in infrastructure
costs.

Using the cloud can also help
reduce your carbon footprint.

In a study commissioned
by AWS, 451 Research found

that AWS infrastructure
is 3.6 times more energy efficient
than the median of U.S.

enterprise data centers surveyed
and up to five times more energy

efficient than the average
in Europe.

They also found that AWS lowered
workload carbon footprints

by nearly 80 percent compared
to enterprise data centers,

and up to 96 percent once AWS
is powered with 100 percent

renewable energy—a target
we’re on path to meet by 2025.
